numbered_ace_sentences: 1. At first glance, I noticed a significant effect of legacy status on the admission rate.
2. A legacy applicant is an applicant whose parent is an alumnus.
3. I noticed that the admission rate is higher for a legacy applicant whose parent's income is below the 99th percentile.
4. I noticed that the admission rate is also higher for a legacy applicant whose parent's income is not in the top 99th percentile.
5. I noticed that applicants whose parents' income is between the 70th percentile and the 90th percentile have a lower admission rate than applicants with slightly lower income.
6. I noticed that applicants whose parents' income is between the 70th percentile and the 90th percentile have a lower admission rate than applicants with slightly higher income.
7. I wonder why the combination of legacy status and parental income below the 99th percentile increases the admission chance more than any other combination in the graph.
9. I see other students spending countless hours to perfect their craft.
10. I see other students studying until dawn.
12. I see other students starting foundations.
13. These students do these activities to increase their admission chances.
14. I think that some applicants with legacy status and higher parental income have higher admission chances than these students.
15. The headline is: Silver Spoon Scholars: How legacy and parental wealth shines in college admissions.
